questions.question: What does TCP/IP stand for?
questions.explanation: TCP/IP is Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol, the foundation of the internet.

questions.question: What is the primary function of a router?
questions.explanation: Routers forward data packets between different networks using IP addresses.

questions.question: Which layer of the OSI model deals with physical transmission of data?
questions.explanation: Physical Layer (Layer 1) handles actual transmission through cables and signals.

questions.question: What is an IP address?
options: A unique identifier for devices on a network
questions.explanation: IP address is a unique numerical identifier for each device on a network.

questions.question: How many bits are in an IPv4 address?
questions.explanation: IPv4 addresses consist of 32 bits, divided into 4 octets.

questions.question: What is a subnet mask used for?
options: Identify network and host portions of an IP address
questions.explanation: Subnet masks determine which part of IP address is network and which is host.

questions.question: What does DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS translates domain names to IP addresses so users can use memorable names.

questions.question: Which port is typically used for HTTP?
questions.explanation: Port 80 is the default port for HTTP (unencrypted web traffic).

questions.question: What is HTTPS?
questions.explanation: HTTPS is HTTP with encryption using SSL/TLS protocols for secure communication.

questions.question: What is the function of a firewall?
questions.explanation: Firewalls monitor incoming and outgoing traffic, blocking unauthorized access.

questions.question: What is a MAC address?
questions.explanation: MAC address is the physical address of a network interface card (48 bits).

questions.question: How many layers does the OSI model have?
questions.explanation: OSI model has 7 layers: Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, Application.

questions.question: What does DHCP provide?
questions.explanation: DHCP automatically assigns IP addresses to devices on a network.

questions.question: What is a LAN?
questions.explanation: LAN is a Local Area Network, typically covering a small geographic area.

questions.question: What is a WAN?
questions.explanation: WAN is a Wide Area Network covering larger geographic areas than LANs.

questions.question: What is a gateway?
options: Device converting data between different network types
questions.explanation: Gateway converts data formats between different network protocols.

questions.question: What does FTP stand for?
questions.explanation: FTP is File Transfer Protocol for uploading/downloading files over networks.

questions.question: Which port is used for SMTP?
questions.explanation: Port 25 is used by SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) for sending emails.

questions.question: What is bandwidth?
questions.explanation: Bandwidth is the maximum amount of data that can be transmitted over a connection.

questions.question: What is latency?
questions.explanation: Latency is the time delay between sending and receiving data.

questions.question: What is a switch?
options: Device connecting devices on same network using MAC addresses
questions.explanation: Switch connects devices on a LAN using MAC addresses (Layer 2).

questions.question: What is NAT?
questions.explanation: NAT translates between private and public IP addresses for security and efficiency.

questions.question: What is VPN?
questions.explanation: VPN creates encrypted tunnel for secure data transmission over public networks.

questions.question: Which protocol is used for secure shell access?
questions.explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) provides encrypted remote access to devices.

questions.question: What is QoS?
questions.explanation: QoS ensures priority and performance for specific network traffic.

questions.question: What does ARP do?
options: Resolves IP addresses to MAC addresses
questions.explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) maps IP addresses to MAC addresses.

questions.question: What is ICMP used for?
questions.explanation: ICMP provides error reporting and diagnostic tools like ping and tracert.

questions.question: What is a proxy server?
options: Server acting as intermediary between clients and other servers
questions.explanation: Proxy server acts as intermediary, caching and filtering traffic.

questions.question: What is load balancing?
options: Distributing network traffic across multiple servers
questions.explanation: Load balancing distributes traffic to prevent server overload.

questions.question: What is a backbone network?
questions.explanation: Backbone is main infrastructure connecting multiple networks.

questions.question: What is Ethernet?
questions.explanation: Ethernet is standard for wired LAN communication.

questions.question: What is WiFi?
questions.explanation: WiFi provides wireless internet access using radio frequencies.

questions.question: What does ISP provide?
questions.explanation: ISP provides internet connectivity to users.

questions.question: What is a DMZ?
questions.explanation: DMZ is buffer zone between trusted internal network and untrusted internet.

questions.question: What is packet switching?
options: Breaking data into packets routed independently
questions.explanation: Packet switching breaks data into packets sent through optimal routes.

questions.question: What is circuit switching?
questions.explanation: Circuit switching establishes dedicated connection for entire communication.

questions.question: What is VLAN?
questions.explanation: VLAN is virtual segmentation of physical network for better organization.

questions.question: What does throughput measure?
questions.explanation: Throughput is actual data transfer rate across a connection.

questions.question: What is a hub?
options: Device connecting devices and broadcasting to all ports
questions.explanation: Hub broadcasts data to all connected devices (less efficient than switch).

questions.question: What is the function of a bridge?
options: Connect network segments, filtering traffic by MAC address
questions.explanation: Bridge connects and segments network, filtering by MAC addresses.

questions.question: What is a subnet mask used for? (additional)
options: Determining network and host portions of an IP address
questions.explanation: Subnet masks separate IP address into network and host identifiers.

questions.question: What is NAT? (additional)
questions.explanation: NAT maps private addresses to public ones for routing across the internet.

questions.question: What is a default gateway? (additional)
options: Router used to forward traffic to other networks
questions.explanation: Default gateway forwards packets to networks outside the local subnet.

questions.question: Which protocol is connection-oriented? (additional)
questions.explanation: TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented transport.

questions.question: What is ARP used for? (additional)
options: Mapping IP addresses to MAC addresses
questions.explanation: ARP resolves layer 3 IP addresses to layer 2 MAC addresses.

questions.question: What is the purpose of DNS? (additional)
options: Translate domain names to IP addresses
questions.explanation: DNS resolves human-readable domain names to numeric IP addresses.

questions.question: What is a MAC address? (additional)
questions.explanation: MAC is a layer 2 hardware identifier assigned to network interfaces.

questions.question: Which device segments collision domains? (additional)
questions.explanation: Switches separate collision domains for each port.

questions.question: What does QoS manage? (additional)
questions.explanation: Quality of Service manages bandwidth and traffic priority.

questions.question: What is a DHCP server role? (additional)
options: Assign IP addresses dynamically to hosts
questions.explanation: DHCP automates IP address assignment for hosts on a network.

questions.question: What is link aggregation? (additional)
options: Combining multiple network links for redundancy and throughput
questions.explanation: Link aggregation increases bandwidth and provides redundancy across links.

questions.question: What is MTU? (additional)
options: Maximum Transmission Unit - largest packet size
questions.explanation: MTU is the largest packet size that can be transmitted without fragmentation.

questions.question: What is latency? (additional)
questions.explanation: Latency refers to the delay in packet delivery across the network.

questions.question: What is a broadcast domain? (additional)
options: Network segment where broadcast frames are forwarded
questions.explanation: Broadcast domains define scope where broadcast traffic is propagated.

questions.question: Which protocol resolves hostnames? (additional)
questions.explanation: DNS resolves domain names to IP addresses.

questions.question: What is the purpose of vlan tagging? (additional)
questions.explanation: Tagging carries VLAN IDs over trunk links between switches.

questions.question: What is a broadcast storm? (additional)
options: Excessive broadcast traffic overwhelming a network
questions.explanation: Broadcast storms can degrade or crash network performance.

questions.question: What is the main use of SNMP? (additional)
questions.explanation: SNMP collects and manages device statistics across the network.

questions.question: What is port forwarding? (additional)
options: Mapping external ports to internal hosts/services
questions.explanation: Port forwarding directs incoming connections to specific internal resources.

questions.question: Why monitor network logs? (additional)
questions.explanation: Logs provide insight for troubleshooting and security investigations.
